title: Clocktower of Ussur
body:
The great Clocktower of Ussur was built over three hundred years beofre the Summer of Darkness, and is so complex that it cannot be recreated. Its inventor, Morüsï Mipẽm, never lived to see it working. It took so long to build, and so long to calibrate, that he died eighty years before its completion.


Mechanics

Morüsï Mipẽm recorded the length of each day for a Moon-Year by measuring the number of rotations of a wound gear, using a specific size gear piece. He measured from when the tip of the rising sun broke he horizon, and when it disappeared. Over the course of his life, he measured from the sun at its lowest position in the sky during Winter, until his death mid-way in the Spring. His students completed his work, and once the sun had reached its highest position in the sky, the number of rotations required for each day from Winter to Summer (and therefore Summer to Winter) had been calculated.

Morüsï Mipẽm's discovery paved the way for the creation of the Ussurian Calendar.
preface: The Clocktower of Ussur is the only working time-telling device in the known lands.
